newsitem.title: USA: U.S. mortgage-backeds slip in lethargic trade.
newsitem.headline: U.S. mortgage-backeds slip in lethargic trade.

text.p: U.S. mortage-backeds dipped into negative territory in thin, directional trade on the heels of a stronger-than-expected rise in a closely watched measure of manufacturing activity, market sources said.
Treasuries cleared the path for pass-throughs in light profit-taking around midday, following the release of the November National Association of Purchasing Management (NAPM) report, traders said.
The November NAPM index rose to 52.7, sharply higher than a 50.8 figure forecast by market experts in a Reuters poll. The October index was pegged at 50.2.
"There was some buying earlier in the day in Fannie Mae 7.0 (percent) and 7.5 (percent) coupons," said one New York-based trader.
He said yield spreads to Treasuries were modestly tighter earlier in the day, but have softened up since midday.
No major bid lists were cited, market players said.
"It's been an extremely quiet day," added one regional trader.
By late afternoon Monday, pass-throughs were 2/32 to 4/32 lower in current coupons and discounts.
Specifically, Ginnie Mae 30-year 7.0 percent coupons were down 3/32 at 99-11/32, yielding 107 basis points over the 10-year Treasury note.
Comparable Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac paper was off 3/32 as well, at 99-04/32 and 99-11/32, respectively.
The 10-year Treasury note was also off 3/32 at 103-07/32 to yield 6.06 percent.
